Definition: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the body's tissues.
Etiology: Iron deficiency, chronic disease, bone marrow issues
Risk_Factors: Nutritional deficiencies, chronic illness, heavy bleeding
Pathophysiology: Reduced oxygen transport due to low red blood cell count
Symptoms: Fatigue, pale skin, shortness of breath
Diagnostic_Methods: Complete blood count, iron studies, reticulocyte count

Definition: A genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to make blood clots, leading to excessive bleeding.
Risk_Factors: Family history of hemophilia, male gender
Pathophysiology: Impaired clot formation due to missing clotting proteins
Symptoms: Excessive bleeding, easy bruising, joint pain
Related_Conditions: Von Willebrand Disease, Factor V Leiden

Definition: A condition in which the body has an abnormally low number of platelets, which help the blood clot.
Pathophysiology: Decreased platelet count causes inadequate clotting

Definition: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells.
Etiology: Genetic mutation in bone marrow cells
Risk_Factors: Radiation exposure, family history of blood cancer
Pathophysiology: Proliferation of immature white blood cells crowds out normal blood cells
Diagnostic_Methods: Bone marrow biopsy, blood tests, genetic testing

Definition: A genetic disorder that causes red blood cells to form a sickle shape, leading to blockages and damage to tissues.
Pathophysiology: Sickle-shaped red blood cells block blood flow and damage tissues
Symptoms: Painful crises, fatigue, swelling in hands and feet

Definition: A genetic disorder in which the body absorbs too much iron from food.
Risk_Factors: Family history, European ancestry, excessive iron intake
Pathophysiology: Excessive iron accumulates in organs causing damage
Symptoms: Fatigue, joint pain, diabetes, heart disease
Diagnostic_Methods: Serum ferritin, liver biopsy, genetic testing

Definition: A bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, a clotting protein.
Pathophysiology: Inadequate von Willebrand factor leads to abnormal bleeding
Diagnostic_Methods: Von Willebrand factor test, bleeding time test

Definition: A blood disorder where the bone marrow produces too many red blood cells, causing thickened blood.
Etiology: Mutation in bone marrow stem cells
Risk_Factors: Smoking, exposure to radiation or toxins
Pathophysiology: Excess red blood cell production increases blood viscosity
Diagnostic_Methods: Complete blood count, bone marrow biopsy, JAK2 mutation test
